DOC.HEAD: Bulldozers Demolish Damaged Buildings, Troops Patrol Against Looting
DOC.TEXT: Workers, slowed by huge slabs of concrete, today searched for more victims of Australia's most destructive earthquake, and police said they believed there were six bodies in the debris of one building. Ten people are known to have been killed in Thursday's quake, and 142 were injured. Demolition crews today started bulldozing heavily damaged buildings and 100 more army troops were dispatched to patrol streets and prevent looting in Newcastle, a major industrial center 75 miles north of Sydney. Police said at least 50 buildings may have to be torn down. The temblor measured 5.5 on the Richter scale and seismologists called it unusually strong for Australia. Rescue efforts centered on the Newcastle Workers' Club, where two floors collapsed onto a basement parking lot during the earthquake. Police said the work was hampered today because the concrete slabs that formed the floor were so heavy. A wall also threatened to collpase. Police spokeswoman Jo Watts said the bodies workers expected to recover were in this wreckage. However, workers did not expect to reach the bodies until Sunday, she said. ``There are also nine cars in the basement but we've located and contacted seven of the owners. Two, we couldn't get the numbers of,'' she said. Ms. Watts said the 10 victims already identified were local people. Emergency teams, which have been working non-stop since the quake hit, had an especially tiring day. ``They started to remove sections of the wall where they believe people are trapped. But it started to give way because of the time spent trying to remove the heavy concrete slabs.'' Initial estimates put the damage at $1 billion, and an official of the Australian Insurance Industry Council said the damage could run into ``hundreds of millions of dollars.'' Australia's biggest earthquake was at Meeberrie, in remote Western Australia in 1941 and measured 7.7 on the Richter scale, a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seimograph. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. A quake measuring 5 can cause considerable damage and one measuring 6 can cause severe damage.
